text:
With the Fourth of July just around the corner,
some of you out there have already started

stockpiling your fireworks arsenal, and no
collection is complete without the old standby
– sparklers.

Today we’re taking a super slow-mo, up-close
look at the chemistry of sparklers, and we’re

shine some light on how these things keep
burning on and on.

Before we light this sucker up, let’s take
a look at what it’s made of.

Sparklers are a thin wire shaft, usually iron,
that has the top coated in a combustible paste.

This paste consists of several components:
Fuels, oxidizers, colorants, and a binder
to make it all stick together.

For a fuel source, this sparkler uses iron,
but there are other substitutions like these

(show alluminum, titanium, and ferrotitanium
alloy).
Okay, so let’s light this sucker up.

When ignited these powdered metals react with
oxygen.

To keep it burning, oxidizers like these decompose
when heated, producing oxygen which fuels
the reaction.

You can see here This gas production then
blasts tiny ignited fragments from the shaft,
producing the classic sparkler effect.

These sparks you’re seeing are metal pieces
that launch out, ignite and burn in the air.

The binder that is most commonly used for
sparklers is dextrin, which is important not

only because it keeps all of these chemicals
uniformly together, but also because it slowly

decomposes during the reaction, slowing the
whole process down for your amazement.

Dextrin is also a pyrotechnic fuel, but it
has a limited effect on sparklers.

Other compounds can be added to the mixture
to give the reaction a little bit of color.

Most commonly you’re going to find yourself
some red, white, and blue sparklers for the

fourth, and to get this good old American
color pallette, you’re going to need these
elements.

When little fragments like these shoot off
of sparklers, they’re incredibly hot.
I’m talking 1000-1600°C hot.

So then you might be wondering why it doesn’t
hurt when your hand is close to the sparks.

Even though they have a super high temperature,
they have very little thermal energy due to
their incredibly small mass.

But be careful, touching the sparkler at the
source of the reaction can cause serious burns.

You can see after ignition that the iron shaft
is glowing bright red.

Iron retains heat much longer than these sparks,
so be careful with that thing!
